context: Fig. 1 demonstrates a typical TD–GC–MS chromatogram of a fasting individual. Fig. 2 shows an IMS spectrum of the same individual recorded by directing the content of the tedlar bag to the inlet of the GC-IMS. Acetone was the most abundant substance identified by both techniques. Acetone is produced by hepatocytes via decarboxylation of excess Acetyl-CoA and is an important physiological metabolic marker in breath. Ketone bodies are oxidized via the Krebs cycle in peripheral tissue. Fasting for 63h led to a 30-fold increase of acetone content in expired air of the individual with successive measurements. Skrupskii reported a 15-fold increase for individuals after fasting for 24h.
